message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a large, oscillating vegetation attached to the tricuspid valve with multiple smaller vegetations on the leaflet tips is highly suggestive of infective endocarditis. The most common causal organism for tricuspid valve endocarditis is Staphylococcus aureus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests infective endocarditis, and the most common organism causing this is Staphylococcus aureus. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of endocarditis in IV drug users, but it usually affects the aortic or mitral valve, not the tricuspid valve. Streptococcus sanguinis and Enterococcus faecalis can also cause endocarditis but are less commonly associated with tricuspid valve involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tricuspid valve is most frequently involved in infectious endocarditis associated with injecting drug use, and Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causal organism in these cases. Streptococcus sanguinis is a common cause of infective endocarditis in patients with underlying valvular disease, but tricuspid valve involvement is rare. Enterococcus faecalis is a less common cause of infective endocarditis and is typically associated with prosthetic valve infections. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a rare cause of infective endocarditis and typically affects the aortic or mitral valves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a large vegetative mass attached to the tricuspid valve and the multiple small vegetations suggest infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing infective endocarditis on a previously normal heart, which is consistent with this patient's history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The oscillating vegetation along with the moderate tricuspid regurgitation suggests infective endocarditis, and Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of tricuspid valve endocarditis, especially in IV drug users.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The large oscillating vegetation suggests infective endocarditis, and Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causal organism for tricuspid valve endocarditis, especially in patients who inject drugs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tricuspid valve is susceptible to endocarditis caused by Staphylococcus aureus, which is often associated with IV drug use. Streptococcus sanguinis and Enterococcus faecalis are less commonly associated with endocarditis, while Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes a more acute form of endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a large, oscillating vegetation on tricuspid valve with multiple small vegetations and moderate tricuspid regurgitation suggests infective endocarditis. Among the options, Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of native valve endocarditis, especially in intravenous drug users.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a large, oscillating vegetation on the tricuspid valve with multiple smaller ones suggests infectious endocarditis, and Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of acute endocarditis and tricuspid valve involvement. The other options are less common causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a large oscillating vegetation attached to the tricuspid valve with multiple small vegetations attached to the tips of the valve leaflets is highly suggestive of infective endocarditis. Among the options, Staphylococcus aureus is the most commonly implicated organism in right-sided endocarditis.
